channel.title: NYT > Home Page
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Tennis Umpire Suspended for Corruption Worked at U.S. Open
item.description: The United States Tennis Association, which operates the Open, blamed “a flaw in our process” for allowing the umpire work as a linesman.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER CLAREY
item.media:description: A breach in procedures allowed Denis Pitner, a Croatian tennis umpire suspended from officiating last August after a corruption inquiry, to continue working some tennis tournaments.

item.title: Police Investigate Double Shooting at Arizona School
item.description: Local news reports said two female students were killed, and a school district representative said the school, in Glendale, was still on lockdown.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE
item.media:description: Parents waited to reunite with their children in Glendale, Ariz., after a shooting on Friday.

item.title: Eurozone Economy Grows, but Total Output Still Lags 2008
item.description: Even as much of the rest of the world has bounced back from the global financial crisis, however fitfully, Europe’s economic core remains soft.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING
item.media:credit: Arnau Bach for The New York Times
item.media:description: The working-class neighborhood of Sant Ildefons in the Catalonia Province of Spain. Greece, Italy and Spain have struggled to recover from the economic crisis of 2008.

item.title: How Cold Is It? Too Cold for an Ice Fest.
item.description: With wind chill temperatures headed toward the minus teens, the keepers of Central Park decided to cancel Saturday’s ice-sculpture celebration.
item.dc:creator: ANDY NEWMAN
item.media:description: This could be you if you venture outdoors on Saturday. Minus the smile.

item.title: Independent, Once a British News Power, Ending Print Edition
item.description: The paper, which shook up Britain’s journalism establishment in the 1980s before falling on hard times, will publish only online, its owner says.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: The demise of the print editions of The Independent — and its weekly counterpart, The Independent on Sunday — is a blow to Britain’s vibrant and fiercely competitive news media scene.

item.title: Snapchat Bets Big on Quick-Fire Approach to Campaign Coverage
item.description: The popular app aims to give its millions of users a chance to experience the daily tumult of the long primary season — in lively 10-second snippets.
item.dc:creator: NICK CORASANITI
item.media:credit: Ian Thomas Jansen-Lonnquist for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peter Hamby, the head of news at Snapchat, at an event for Gov. John Kasich in Manchester, N.H., last week.

item.title: Disparity in Life Spans of the Rich and the Poor Is Growing
item.description: Despite advances in medicine, a longevity gap that has long favored wealthy Americans has more than doubled since the 1970s, researchers say.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patients at the Free Clinic in Newton, N.J. Researchers debate whether expanding access to health care will shrink the gap in life expectancy between the rich and the poor.

item.title: Review: ‘The Room,’ a Pinter Play That Won’t Be Onstage for Long
item.description: The Wooster Group’s production of Harold Pinter’s first play seems doomed not to be seen after Sunday.
item.dc:creator: LAURA COLLINS-HUGHES
item.media:description: Ari Fliakos and Kate Valk in Harold Pinter’s “The Room,” at Redcat in Los Angeles.

item.title: New York Today: New York Today: How to Beat the Cold
item.description: Friday: Keeping warm, brrrrrrrutally cold weather, and presidential punctuation.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN WOLFE
item.media:credit: Christian Hansen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Putting on a brave face for the Arctic-style temperatures.

item.title: U.S. Drawing Southeast Asia Closer With California Summit
item.description: Competition with China will be the subtext as President Obama hosts Asean leaders beginning on Monday in Rancho Mirage, Calif.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: President Obama on his way out of the White House. Since his administration’s ‘‘pivot to Asia,’’ America has been in direct competition with China for economic power in Southeast Asia.

item.title: Zika Virus Test Is ‘Weeks, Not Years’ Away, W.H.O. Says
item.description: Large-scale clinical trials for a potential vaccine are not expected for at least 18 months, however, the World Health Organization said.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: A mother held her 4-month-old son, who was born with microcephaly, in Olinda, Brazil, on Thursday.

item.title: Skid in Oil Prices Pulls the Recycling Industry Down With It
item.description: As oil prices sink, it becomes cheaper to make new plastic and other materials than it is to recycle them from garbage, hitting the recycling industry hard.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GELLES
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: A worker cleaning equipment used to process recycling material at the Waste Management facility in Newark.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Syria, Oregon, Albert Einstein
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: ADEEL HASSAN
item.media:description: Hillary Clinton introduced many new lines of attack on Bernie Sanders in Thursday’s debate, including on foreign affairs.

item.title: Public Editor's Journal: Is Global Expansion Good for Times Readers?
item.description: A Spanish-language site goes live, joining a Chinese-language site, with more to come.
item.dc:creator: MARGARET SULLIVAN

item.title: Sunni Resentment Muddles Prospect of Reunifying Iraq After ISIS
item.description: Without plans for reconciliation and rebuilding places like Anbar, critics say, the American approach risks leaving fertile ground for the Islamic State.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Iraqis who fled regions controlled by the Islamic State near Falluja arrived on the eastern outskirts of Ramadi on Tuesday after pro-government troops retook the area.

item.title: Tension Simmers as Cubans Breeze Across U.S. Border
item.description: More Cubans are entering the country under a law passed in 1966, creating a disparity at the border, where Central Americans are detained and sent to immigration court.
item.dc:creator: JULIA PRESTON
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The port of entry in Laredo, where United States Customs and Border Protection agents worked this month to process immigrants.

item.title: One Patient’s Story: ‘That’s a Kill Shot’
item.description: “This American Life,” in a partnership with The New York Times, tells the story of one family caught in the dangerous crossover of mental health treatment and security in American hospitals.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH ROSENTHAL
item.media:description: Alan Pean, with his mother and father, after he was shot last August in St. Joseph Medical Center in Houston.

item.title: When the Hospital Fires the Bullet
item.description: More and more hospital guards across the country carry weapons, sparking a fierce debate over whether that improves safety or endangers patients.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH ROSENTHAL
item.media:credit: Chad Batka for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the center of Alan Pean’s chest is the scar left by a hospital security officer’s bullet last August.

item.title: Below Zero: How Negative Interest Rates Could Remake the Global Financial System
item.description: It’s not clear that it would even be legal in the United States.
item.dc:creator: NEIL IRWIN
item.media:description: Janet Yellen said the Fed did not envision having to institute negative interest rates.

item.title: Eurozone Economy Grows, but Total Output Still Lags Behind 2008
item.description: Even as much of the rest of the world has bounced back from the global financial crisis, however fitfully, Europe’s economic core remains soft.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING
item.media:credit: Arnau Bach for The New York Times
item.media:description: The working-class neighborhood of Sant Ildefons in the Catalonia Province of Spain. Greece, Italy and Spain have struggled to recover from the economic crisis of 2008.
